moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 h6 4. d3 Bc5: I'm not too keen on this move. It compromises your kingside pawn structure too much. If you want to exchange bishops, play Qe2 first.
moves.5... Bxe3 6. fxe3 Nf6 7. h3: Another weakening move. There is now a big hole on g3 just waiting for Black's knight.
moves.7... d6 8. O-O Nh5 9. Nh2: The knight is out of the game here and your threat is easily defended.
moves.10. Nc3 g5: Black needs to safeguard his king before playing moves like this.
moves.11. Qf3 Be6 12. Bxe6 fxe6 13. Qxf6 Qxf6: Black should resign at this point!
moves.14... Ke7 15. Raf1 Rag8 16. Ng4: Try to work out what your opponent's response will be before you make a move. Rf7  was the obvious move.
moves.18. Kh1: This doesn't help, Black can still play ...g3. The best solution was Rf7  followed by R1f6, vacating f1 for the knight.
moves.18... gxh3: ...g3 would have put Black right back in the game.
moves.19. gxh3 Rg3 20. Rf6f3 Rhg8 21. Rxg3 Rxg: At this point White needs to make a plan. The first priority is activate the knight on h2.
moves.30. Ng4 Ne7 31. Rf8 Rg7 32. Ra8 c6 33. R: Don't be in a hurr to push your extra pawn. Improve the position of your knight on e2 first (e2-c1-d3).
moves.35... bxa4 36. Rxa4 Ng6 37. c4: This weakens your pawn on b4. The best plan was still to activate the knight on e2. But before you can do that you must challenge Black's control of the f-file by playing your rook to f3 (via a3).
moves.37... Ne7 38. Ra5 Ng6 39. c5+ Ke6 40. Ng: This was your opportunity to exchange rooks by playing 40.Ra6 Kd7 41.Ra7 . The more pieces go off, the bigger your advantage becomes.
moves.40... Nf4+ 41. Kh2 Nh5: Black could have won the b-pawn by playing 41...Rb7 42.Ra4 Nd3.
moves.42. Ra6 Rf4 43. Rxc6+ Ke7 44. Nxe5: I don't think you needed another pawn! You should have been able to see the consequences.
